titlePart.entryReference: making optical elements or apparatus , , , or other appropriate sub-classes or classes
measuring-instruments, see the relevant sub-class of class , e.g. optical rangefinders
testing of optical elements, systems, or apparatus
optical elements structurally combined with electric discharge tubes , ,
combination of optical elements with television receivers

noteParagraph.text: In this sub-class, the following terms are used with the meanings indicated:
"Simple lens or prism" denotes a single lens or prism.

"Compound lens or prism" denotes an optical member, the constituents of which either are close together without air-space or (except in group ) are "in broken contact", i.e. with the air-space between the constituents having no essential optical influence
"Objective" denotes a lens or an optical system designed to produce a real image of a real object.
"Eyepiece" denotes a lens or an optical system designed to produce a virtual image for viewing by the eye or by another optical system.
"Front" and "rear" are determined by looking from the more distant conjugate.
"Optical" applies not only to visible light but also to ultra-violet and infra-red radiations.

titlePart.text: Optical elements characterised by the material of which they are made
made of crystals, e.g. rock-salt, semiconductors
made of organic materials, e.g. plastics
made of fluids in transparent cells
Coatings produced by application to, or surface treatment of, optical elements, e.g. anti-reflection coatings
by surface treatment, e.g. by irradiation

titlePart.entryReference: spectacle lenses or contact lenses for the eyes

titlePart.text: with continuous faces that are rotationally symmetrical but deviate from a true sphere
with discontinuous faces, e.g. Fresnel lens
cube corner, trihedral or triple reflector type
plural reflecting elements forming part of a unitary plate or sheet
transparent spheres being embedded in matrix
plural curved refracting elements forming part of a unitary body
plural reflecting elements forming part of a unitary body
the relative position of the fibres being the same at both ends, e.g. for transporting images

titlePart.entryReference: control of light by electric, magnetic, electromagnetic or acoustic means
transmission of information by optical means
production and processing of single crystals
processes or apparatus for producing holograms

titlePart.text: Mountings, adjusting means, or light-tight connections, for optical elements
with mechanism for focusing or varying magnification
adapted to co-operate with a remote control mechanism
by relative axial movement of several lenses, e.g. of varifocal objective lens
with mechanism for automatically focusing or varying magnification
Adjusting pupillary distance of binocular pairs
Light-tight connections for movable optical elements
Optical objectives characterised both by the number of the components and their arrangements according to their sign, i.e. + or -

noteParagraph.text: For the purposes of this group, a component is deemed to be a simple lens or a compound lens or a divided lens equivalent to a simple or to a compound lens.

titlePart.text: only one component having a compound lens
the rear component having the compound
the middle component having the compound
two of the components having compound lenses
the front and rear components having compound lenses
the middle and rear components having compound lenses
the middle component being a - compound meniscus having a + lens

noteParagraph.text: In groups , , and , the first-mentioned applicable group takes precedence over later-mentioned groups.

titlePart.text: Optical objectives characterised by the total number of simple and compound lenses forming the objective and their arrangement

noteParagraph.text: For the purposes of this group, lenses in broken contact are counted separately. Simple lenses are denoted by L, compounds by C, and the front lens is mentioned first.

titlePart.text: Optical objectives specially designed for the purposes specified below
Telephoto objectives, i.e. systems of the type +- in which the distance from the front vertex to the image plane is less than the equivalent focal length
for use with infra-red or ultra-violet radiation
for use in conjunction with image converters or intensifiers
with lenses having one or more non-spherical faces, e.g. for reducing geometrical aberration
for reproducing or copying at short object distances
Optical objectives with means for varying the magnification
by changing, adding, or subtracting a part of the objective, e.g. convertible objective
by adding a part, e.g. close-up attachment
by relative movement of the parts to vary the equivalent focal length of the objective continuously
having two parts with different and coupled movements relative to the image plane
with a further part movable for focusing
Systems with reflecting surfaces, with or without refracting elements
Catoptric systems, e.g. image erecting and reversing system
Arrangements with more than one light-path, e.g. for comparing two specimens
Microscope slides, e.g. mounting specimens on microscope slides
titlePart.entryReference: means for supporting the objects or the materials to be analysed in electron microscopes

titlePart.text: arranged for photographic purposes or projection purposes
Instruments for viewing the inside of hollow bodies
for the purpose of beam splitting or combining, e.g. fitted with eyepieces for more than one observer
having a focusing action, e.g. parabolic mirror
reflecting into the field of view additional indications, e.g. from collimator
with means for image conversion or intensification
titlePart.entryReference: objectives for image conversion or intensification
electrical image converters with optical input and optical output

titlePart.text: Underwater equipments, e.g. for submarine periscope
with means for illuminating object viewed
affording a wide-angle view, e.g. through a spy-hole

titlePart.entryReference: means for bringing-about special optical effects in shop-windows, show-cases , e.g.
designs or pictures characterised by special light effects
applications of optical scanning systems, see the relevant sub-classes, e.g. , , ,

titlePart.text: for optical projection, e.g. combination of mirror and condenser and objective
for imaging minute objects, e.g. light-pointer
for producing stereoscopic or other three-dimensional effects
involving reflecting prisms and mirrors only
Fiducial marks and measuring scales within the optical system

noteParagraph.text: The filter may be in any plane, e.g. the image or the Fourier transfer plane.

titlePart.text: Optics using evanescent waves, i.e. inhomogeneous waves

titlePart.entryReference: means for converting the output of a sensing member using diffraction gratings

titlePart.text: Optical apparatus specially adapted for adjusting optical elements during the assembly of optical systems
titlePart.entryReference: adjusting means being part of the system to be assembled

titlePart.text: Imaging systems using optical elements for stabilisation of the lateral and angular position of the image
